title: JKSSB JE (Civil) Focused Assessment: Shear Force, Bending Moment, and Simple Stress-Strain Analysis
description: This professional academic assessment is meticulously designed for aspirants of the JKSSB Junior Engineer (Civil) examination. It provides a focused evaluation of core undergraduate-level concepts within Mechanics and Structural Analysis, specifically targeting Shear Force and Bending Moment diagrams for statically determinate beams, and the fundamental principles of Simple Stress and Strain relationships ($ \sigma = E\epsilon $). The test features a balanced mix of practical and conceptual questions that reflect the difficulty and standards of the JKSSB exam, enabling candidates to rigorously test their analytical skills and theoretical knowledge.

questions.text: A simply supported beam of span 'L' carries a uniformly distributed load (UDL) of 'w' per unit length. The shape of the Bending Moment Diagram (BMD) will be a:
questions.explanation: The relationship between load (w), shear force (V), and bending moment (M) is $dV/dx = -w$ and $dM/dx = V$. For a constant load (UDL), the shear force diagram is linear (1st degree). Integrating a linear function results in a bending moment diagram that is a parabolic curve (2nd degree).

questions.text: When a tensile load is applied to a flat plate with a circular hole in the center, the maximum stress occurs:

options.text: At the center of the hole.
At the edges of the plate, far from the hole.
At the edge of the hole, on the transverse diameter.

questions.explanation: The hole acts as a stress concentrator. The lines of stress must flow around the discontinuity, causing them to crowd together at the edges of the hole perpendicular to the applied load. This results in a localized stress that is significantly higher than the average nominal stress.

topics: Bending moment and shear force in statically determinate beams — Mechanics and Structural Analysis
Simple stress and strain relationship — Mechanics and Structural Analysis
